info.title: What is a rule?

abstract.para: Among the most common measures these days to keep players from making short draws are the anti-drawing rules that forbid them to end a game peacefully before a certain number of moves have been made.

info.teaser: Nikita Vitiugov: ‘It isn’t a rule when somebody can break it.’

article.para:
Among the most common measures these days to keep players from making short draws are the anti-drawing rules that forbid them to end a game peacefully before a certain number of moves have been made. Despite repeated criticism, these rules have been remarkably successful, which in itself says a lot about the ambitions of many chess players when they are not forced to play. Still, these anti-drawing rules are not always effective, as witness this year’s Gibraltar Chess Congress. One of the highlights were the varied and popular ‘Master Classes’, and the most popular of the five presented this year was by Vassily Ivanchuk, who was highly animated as he took questions from the audience and host Stuart Conquest for nearly half an hour. The Master Class was ostensibly a form of penance, for a minor infraction of the tournament rule. Earlier in the day, Ivanchuk’s seventh round pairing with Le Quang Liem ended after just fourteen moves in an equal and symmetrical position, while the tournament regulations mandated that games be played out to at least move 30. The players had left the playing hall before the anomaly was noticed by the arbiters and the organizers, who initially considered requiring the game to be replayed. Le actually remained near the hall for quite some time awaiting a decision from his opponent, who was reluctant to return. Ivanchuk, evidently, was in no mood to replay the game. Ironically, a similarly quick draw occurred between two amateur players during the same round, and they were in fact asked to replay their game. Ultimately the matter was simply dropped. The comment of later winner Nikita Vitiugov was nicely succinct: ‘It isn’t a rule when somebody can break it.’
Having saved energy earlier in the day, Vassily Ivanchuk was ready to answer any question Stuart Conquest could think of.
Macauley Peterson
